position.marginalia_text: Tria omnium odiosissima, pra[e]sertim serio viro: Ignorantia; Ignauia; et

marginalia.translation: Three things are most hateful, especially to a serious man: ignornace, slothfulness, and melancholy. Three repulsive beasts.
Others are mostly seized, he mostly seizes upon.

position.marginalia_text: ( Sola virorum generositas, Scientia; industria; alacritas.)

marginalia.translation: Knowledge is the only generosity of men. Industriousness. Quickness.
... through skill and faith. They are beloved by favor both kingly and divine, and by human fortune, and they are honored among the first.

position.marginalia_text: Nihil omnium rerum sordidius ignoranti: ignauo: tristi.

marginalia.translation: Of all things nothing is more base than an ignorant man, a lazy man, a sad man.

position.marginalia_text: Malo corporis, animiq[ue], nobilitatem, quàm fortuna[e].

marginalia.translation: I prefer nobility of body and mind to that of fortune.

position.marginalia_text: { nemo omniu[m], satis robustus, aut durus: ne celer quidem, aut diligens satis.

marginalia.translation: No one is ever robust or hard enough: nor indeed swift or careful enough.

position.marginalia_text: Viuida Ironia statim explodat quamcunq[ue] subrepentem Melancholiam: qua[e] tum toleranda Solummodò, cum vir vult esse bestia.

marginalia.translation: A lively irony immediately drives off any sort of grovelling melancholy, which should only be supported when a man wants to be a beast.
